abstract: Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case Monday for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.
snippet: Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case Monday for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Nov. 26 — Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from the rival mining company BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case Monday, trying to persuade shareholders to hold out for a better offer.

headline.main: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of Bid
headline.print_headline: Rio Tinto Tells Shareholders to Wait for a Better Bid Than BHP’s

abstract: While Rio Tinto continued Monday to outline why a $153 billion takeover proposal from rival mining company BHP Billiton was not in its best interests, the company nevertheless seemed to signal that it was receptive to suitors.
lead_paragraph: While Rio Tinto continued Monday to outline why a $153 billion takeover proposal from rival mining company BHP Billiton was not in its best interests, the company nevertheless seemed to signal that it was receptive to suitors.

headline.main: Rio Tinto Is Open to Offers — at the Right Price
